name: Product Hero with Benefit Badge
description: Bold claim headline with comparison badge and humorous parenthetical subline

copyPlacements.description: Bold, simple claim statement. Pattern: '[Thing] is the new [thing]' or '[Benefit] in [format]' e.g. 'Fiber is the new protein.' Keep it punchy and declarative.
Comparison-based benefit claim. Pattern: 'MORE [X] THAN [Y]' e.g. 'MORE FIBER THAN 2 CUPS OF BROCCOLI'. Must be specific and comparative.
Playful parenthetical that adds personality. Pattern: '(Especially if you [relatable scenario])' - casual, self-aware humor.
Brand name on package
Product category descriptor on packaging e.g. 'Superfoods Greens Gummies'

specs.styleNotes: Clean, health-focused design with warm background and hand-held product shot. Headline is a bold declarative claim. Benefit badge uses comparison format. Humorous subline adds personality in parentheses. Keep all copy SHORT and punchy.

name: Product Hero with Social Proof
description: Minimal product hero with conversational headline and social proof badge

copyPlacements.description: Conversational headline with *emphasis* on key benefit phrase. Pattern: 'The [benefit phrase] for [audience]' e.g. 'The *no-makeup makeup* for chronically late people'
Supporting benefit statement that expands on the headline promise
Star rating and review count. Pattern: '★★★★★ [number] [X] STAR REVIEWS' e.g. '★★★★★ 29,931 5 STAR REVIEWS'

specs.styleNotes: Clean, minimal design with elegant serif headline featuring italic emphasis on key phrase. Product hero shot centered with social proof badge at bottom. Keep copy tight and conversational.

name: Product Benefits List with Hero Shot
description: Numbered benefits list with product hero shot - scannable format

copyPlacements.description: Intro headline that sets up the list. Pattern: '[X] benefits of [product]'s [quality]:' e.g. '6 benefits of AG1's natural, high-quality ingredients:' - ends with colon to introduce the list.

Output 6 benefits, EACH ON ITS OWN LINE. Each benefit is 2-4 words max - just the benefit name, NO explanations. Format exactly like this:
1. Focus & Energy
2. Gut Health
3. Nutrient Replenishment
4. Stress & Mood Balance
5. Immune Health
6. Healthy Aging

copyPlacements.style: large, bold, white text on product
copyPlacements.description: Brand/product name on packaging
Product descriptor on packaging. Pattern: '[Adjective] + [Adjective] [Category]' e.g. 'Comprehensive + Convenient Daily Nutrition'

specs.styleNotes: Clean, minimalist design with numbered benefits list on left and product hero shot on right. Benefits must be SHORT (2-4 words each) - just the benefit name, not full sentences or explanations. The headline introduces the list, benefits are scannable bullet points.

name: Split Product Benefits with Guarantee
description: Four-quadrant layout with bold headline, guarantee callout, product shot, and ingredient benefits list

copyPlacements.description: Brand name displayed small above headline
Bold benefit claim with timeframe or result. Pattern: '[RESULT] IN [TIME]' e.g. 'BETTER FOCUS IN 60 MINS'
Risk-reversal guarantee statement. Pattern: 'Or [Guarantee]' e.g. 'Or Get Your Money Back'
Ingredient benefit line. Pattern: '[Ingredient] for [benefit]' e.g. 'Lion's Mane for memory & learning'
Ingredient benefit line. Pattern: '[Ingredient] to [benefit]' e.g. 'CDP Choline to support attention'
Ingredient benefit line. Pattern: '[Ingredient] provides [benefit]' e.g. '7-8 DHF provides neuroprotection'
Product name as shown on packaging

specs.styleNotes: Four-quadrant split layout. Top-left: bold headline. Top-right: guarantee with product hero shot. Bottom-left: product packaging shot. Bottom-right: stacked ingredient benefits. Benefits must be single lines following the pattern '[Ingredient/Feature] for/to/provides [benefit keyword]'. Keep all copy tight and scannable.

name: Negative Quote-Based Product Hero
description: Sarcastic quote format using ironic statements no one would say to highlight the problem

copyPlacements.description: Sarcastic/ironic quote - something NOBODY would ever say. Pattern: 'I WANT [BAD THING]' e.g. 'I WANT MICROPLASTICS IN MY BREASTMILK'. Must be absurd and highlight the problem the product solves.
Sarcastic attribution. Pattern: '— No [person] ever' e.g. '— No mom ever'. NOT a real testimonial name.
Brand name
Product name/descriptor on packaging e.g. 'MICROPLASTIC BINDING PROBIOTIC'
Brief usage or dosage info

specs.styleNotes: Dark, moody product photography. The quote must be IRONIC - something absurd that nobody would say, highlighting the problem. Attribution is sarcastic ('No mom ever'), NOT a real person testimonial. This format uses humor through absurdity.

name: News Article Headline + Image
description: Fake news article layout with brand as publication, curiosity-driven headline, and testimonial body

copyPlacements.description: Brand name styled as publication/magazine name

Curiosity-driven news headline. Pattern: '[Persona] Swears by This [Benefit] Hack' e.g. 'Teacher Swears by This Morning Beauty Hack'. Must include relatable persona, use 'Swears by/Discovers/Relies on', include 'This' for curiosity gap. NO product or brand name.
Related topic links separated by pipe. Pattern: '[Topic] | "[Teaser quote]"' e.g. '2-Min Routine | "The ultimate healthy glow"'

1-2 sentence article intro with named person quote. Pattern: '[Title] [Full Name] says, "This is my little [morning/daily] secret."' e.g. '11th Grade teacher Sarah Jenkins says, "This is my little morning secret."'

specs.styleNotes: Styled like a real news article or blog post. Brand appears as publication name in masthead. Headline creates curiosity without revealing product. Body text includes a named person with their title giving a personal testimonial quote. Should feel like journalism, not advertising.

name: Native Problem-Solution
description: IG Story native format with bubble text question and helpful product solution - creator POV

copyPlacements.description: Category/community topic label e.g. 'GLP-1 Q&A', 'Skincare Help', 'Morning Routine'

copyPlacements.style: IG Story bubble text, casual, first-person
copyPlacements.description: MUST BE A QUESTION. Vulnerable first-person question in IG Story bubble text style. Pattern: '[Question about problem]?' e.g. 'how do you manage bloating??' or 'anyone else struggle with [problem]?' ALWAYS ends with a question mark. Casual, imperfect, uses ellipses or emoji optional. Write from CREATOR POV, not brand voice.

Helpful tip pointing to product as solution. Pattern: '[Amount] of [ingredient] helps [solve problem]' e.g. '6g of fiber helps relieve bloating and constipation.' Should feel like a friend sharing a tip, not brand marketing.

specs.styleNotes: IG Story native format. The bubble text MUST be phrased as a QUESTION - someone asking for help or advice. Solution callout feels like a helpful friend sharing what worked for them, with handwritten annotation style pointing to the product. CRITICAL: All copy must be written from creator/user POV, NOT brand voice. Casual, imperfect, human. The bubble question is the hook - it must be a question that resonates with the audience's struggles.

name: Product Hero with Benefit Headline
description: Simple format with poetic benefit headline and product hero with stats

copyPlacements.description: Poetic benefit headline with parallel structure. Pattern: 'The [Adjective] [Category] for Your [Adjective] [Outcome].' e.g. 'The Optimal Protein for Your Optimal Form.' Use repetition or parallelism for rhythm.
3 key product stats separated by pipes. Pattern: '[Stat] | [Stat] | [Stat]' e.g. '28g Protein | 150 Calories | 0g Sugar'. Use specific numbers.

specs.styleNotes: Clean, minimal format. Large poetic headline at top with parallel structure for rhythm. Product hero shot below with key stats on the packaging. Only 2 copy zones needed - headline and stats. Keep headline elegant and memorable.

name: Post It
description: UGC-style photo with handwritten post-it note callout

copyPlacements.description: Short post-it style callout from creator POV. Should feel like a personal note/recommendation. Pattern: 'Holy Grail [Benefit]' or 'My [Timeframe] Secret' or '[Superlative] [Category]'. e.g. 'Holy Grail Anti-aging Ingredients'. Keep it SHORT and punchy - this is a tiny post-it note.

specs.styleNotes: UGC-style product photo with a handwritten post-it note overlay. The note should feel like a creator's personal recommendation - casual, authentic, like they're sharing a secret. Only ONE copy zone - the post-it note. Keep it extremely short.

name: Premium Product Showcase with Ingredients
description: Minimal premium format with simple ingredient list above product hero

copyPlacements.description: Simple comma-separated list of 3-4 key ingredients. Pattern: '[ingredient], [ingredient], [ingredient]' e.g. 'Cardamom, black tang seaweed, sandalwood'. Lowercase, no periods, elegant and minimal. Just the ingredient names - no benefits or explanations.

specs.styleNotes: Ultra-minimal premium format. Only ONE copy zone - a simple ingredient list at top. Product hero shot below. The ingredient list should feel like a luxury fragrance note list - elegant, simple, evocative. No headlines, no taglines, no product descriptions - just ingredients and product.

name: Product Hero with Background Texture
description: Product hero on textured ingredient/lifestyle background with bold headline and CTA button

copyPlacements.description: Seasonal or benefit-driven headline. Pattern: '[Action] the [timeframe] [benefit].' or '[Benefit] [statement].' e.g. 'Start the year hydrated.' Short, punchy, ends with period.
Product announcement or action CTA. Pattern: '[Product/Flavor] is here' or 'Try [Product] now' e.g. 'Lychee is here'. Can announce new product/flavor or drive action.

specs.styleNotes: Product packaging on textured background (fruit, ingredients, lifestyle). Bold headline at top, pill-shaped CTA button below. Only 2 copy zones - headline and CTA. Background texture should relate to product flavor/benefit. Clean and appetizing.

name: What It's Not Product Hero with Social Proof
description: Contrarian headline calling out what the product ISN'T, with subhead and social proof

copyPlacements.description: Contrarian headline calling out what the product ISN'T or a negative the product avoids. Pattern: '[Bad thing] isn't [a feature/ingredient]' e.g. 'Gross isn't an active ingredient'. Challenges category norms with wit.

Supporting line that expands on the headline with what the product DOES do. Pattern: '[Product type] that actually [works/tastes good], and [avoids negative]' e.g. 'Greens that actually work, and taste nothing like swamp water.'
Review count with star rating. Pattern: '[Number]+ ★★★★★ reviews' e.g. '50,000+ ★★★★★ reviews'. All on one line.
Trust/credibility statement. Pattern: '[Certification] and [certification] tested.' e.g. 'Clinically and third-party tested.' Short credibility proof point.

specs.styleNotes: Bold contrarian messaging that calls out category problems. Headline challenges what competitors do wrong. Subhead pivots to positive product benefit. Social proof adds credibility. Trust badge at bottom reinforces quality. Product hero in center.

name: 5 Reasons Why
description: Listicle format with 5 short reasons and social proof badge

copyPlacements.description: Listicle headline with '5 reasons' intro. Pattern: '5 reasons to [switch/try/choose] [from X to Y / product]' e.g. '5 reasons to switch from powders to grüns gummies'. The '5 reasons' can be in script style.

5 SHORT reasons, EACH ON ITS OWN LINE. Each reason is ONE short phrase (4-8 words max). Format exactly like:
1. Enjoy taking them
2. Easy to stay consistent
3. Same (or more) nutrients
4. No gummy fillers
5. Clinically tested

NO long sentences. NO explanations. Just the benefit phrase.
Review count with stars in pill badge. Pattern: '[Number]+ ★★★★★ reviews' e.g. '50,000+ ★★★★★ reviews'. All on one line.

specs.styleNotes: Listicle format with numbered reasons on left, product hero on right. CRITICAL: Each reason must be SHORT (4-8 words) - just the benefit, not a full sentence or explanation. This is scannable content. Social proof badge at bottom adds credibility.

name: Problem Unaware Simple Static
description: Problem-focused headline for cold audiences who don't know they have a problem - NO product mention

copyPlacements.description: First part of shocking problem statement. Pattern: '[Problem cause] can' e.g. 'Dehydration can', 'Skipping SPF can', 'Poor sleep can'. Sets up the shocking consequence. DO NOT mention the product or brand.

Shocking consequence with specific stat or timeframe. Pattern: 'take [X] years off your [thing]'s life' or 'age your skin [X] years' e.g. 'take 2 years off your dog's life', 'make you look 10 years older'. MUST be specific and alarming. NO product mention.

specs.styleNotes: CRITICAL: This is a PROBLEM-UNAWARE format for COLD audiences. The headline is 100% about the PROBLEM, NOT the product. The goal is to stop scrolling by making the audience realize they have a problem they didn't know about. Use shocking stats, specific numbers, and emotional consequences. The image should be relatable lifestyle (not product-focused). NO product names, NO benefits, NO CTAs. Pure problem education.
bestFor: products solving problems people don't know they have

name: Product Story Highlight
description: Instagram Story format with mashup headline, subhead, and 3 sensory feature callouts

copyPlacements.description: Mashup headline combining two concepts. Pattern: '[Thing A] Meets [Thing B]' e.g. 'Iced Coffee Meets Candy', 'Skincare Meets Makeup', 'Glow Meets Coverage'. Short and punchy.
Supporting line that explains the mashup. Pattern: 'Real [ingredient] You Can [action]' or '[Benefit] in [form]' e.g. 'Real Arabica You Can Eat'. Short and explanatory.
Sensory/ingredient callout. Pattern: '[Ingredient] & [ingredient] [feature]' e.g. 'Arabica coffee & cocoa powder coating'. Describes what's IN the product.
Sensory experience callout. Pattern: '[Adverb] [ADJECTIVE] [Sensation]' e.g. 'Curiously ICY Sensation'. Describes how it FEELS.
Texture/taste callout. Pattern: '[Texture]-[texture] [quality], [quality]' e.g. 'Cocoa-butter smooth, mellow sweetness'. Describes texture and taste.
Soft CTA prompt. Pattern: 'Try [Key Benefit] ↓' e.g. 'Try Icy Refreshment ↓'. Invites action without being pushy.

specs.styleNotes: Instagram Story format (9:16). Mashup headline at top catches attention. 3 floating feature callouts describe sensory experience around the product. Action prompt at bottom leads to swipe. Keep ALL copy SHORT - this is a story format with limited real estate. Feature callouts should be sensory and descriptive, not benefit-focused.
